Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Communicate and offer small mutual help like receiving packages or checking in during emergencies
Situation2: A storm advisory for tonight mentions possible delays and the elderly neighbor lives alone on the same floor.
Story:
I was just about to text my sister, inviting her to join me and my friends for dinner, when the storm advisory flashed on my phone. The weather app warned of heavy rain and possible power outages tonight. My sister and I had been working on including each other more in our social lives, and I knew she’d be happy to come along. She’d mentioned feeling left out lately, and I wanted to show her she mattered.

But then I remembered Mrs. Kim, my elderly neighbor down the hall. She lived alone, and last time there was a storm, she’d been anxious and called me for help when her lights flickered. I knew she’d appreciate someone checking in, maybe even staying nearby in case things got bad. I felt torn—my sister expected me to make her feel included, but Mrs. Kim might need me tonight, too. I stared at my phone, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in, unsure which message to send first.
